could also be searched by software in the same way as the reduction reaction. After obtaining the equations, ANSYS CFD and other software can be used to calculate the fluid dynamics. Modeling typically assumes that the reactor is simplified to a two-dimensional, axisymmetric domain with uniform gas distribution and laminar flow maintained by consistent pore channels with adiabatic sidewalls. Boundary conditions, material properties, and heat source terms can be defined by the UDF (coupled ANSYS FLUENT solver programming function). This is followed by a pressure-velocity fit analysis, and finally the energy equation is discretized.

Reactor modeling is a cost-effective approach to achieving verification of reactor design solutions. In this section, heat transfer to the reactor volume and temperature homogenization are targeted, while the effect of thermochemical reaction processes on the system is considered. The numerical simulation method can effectively analyze the variation of temperature distribution inside the reactor under the influence of different reactor structural parameters, and the numerical simulation results can be used as a basis for the development and design of solar reactors for hydrogen production.

As the simulation results are idealized, the actual design of the reactor can be progressed, the internal structure of reactor is shown in Fig. 15 (b). Three main criteria for practical processing and testing need to be considered during the design process: geometric design, heat transfer flow design and performance design, the specific design elements are shown in Fig. 16 .

The shape of the absorber is always the first essential design consideration. Daabo et al. [173] investigated the optical efficiency of three common receiver geometries, namely cylindrical, spherical, and conical. They found that the amount of light reflected from the receiver is related to the absorption rate and that different geometries exhibit varying optical losses at different absorption rates. For instance, at an absorption rate of 85%, the spherical receiver experienced the most light loss, and the cylindrical receiver was preferred. However, at an absorption rate of 75%, the optical efficiency of the cylindrical shape was only 63% [173]. Generally, of several common direct receivers, the optical efficiency of spherical receivers at different absorption rates or focal positions is inferior to that of receivers with the other two geometries, while conical receivers exhibit the highest energy absorption. However, the combination of reactors with different types of solar concentrating methods leads to different conclusions.

The design of reactor wall thickness needs to consider the steady-state temperature distribution inside the thermochemical cycle reactor to ensure that the temperature of the inner layer of the thermal insulation material and the shell insulation material can meet the heat resistance requirements of each material layer [174]. For example, for a reactor operating at a temperature of 1500 °C, the optimal thickness of the inner and outer material is approximately 6 cm, which avoids significant heat loss due to insulation material being too thin while still considering the cost of materials.

The optimal efficiency of a solar reactor is achieved when the beam direction is perpendicular to the incident surface on the reactor [175]. Sun et al. [176] investigated the effect of focus position on efficiency and found that the thermocchemical cycle system efficiency significantly improved when the incident light angle was reduced from 90° to 53°. However, the optimal efficiency decreased after the focus position exceeded 70 mm.

The aperture ratio, which represents the proportion of the diameter of the quartz window to the focal length, is a vital design factor for a solar reactor. Directly heated reactors require transparent windows to be built at the radiation inlet and outlet sites to fulfill the reaction's energy demands. To prevent thermal stress and reduce secondary radiation losses, it is crucial to maintain sufficient solar radiation input by minimizing the adaptation window aperture size. Deviating from the optimal aperture ratio can decrease sunlight transmittance, so it is necessary to consider this when using simulated sunlight for experiments. Additionally, the reactor's inner diameter and length are crucial design considerations [177,178].

In many reactor designs, the gas inlet is located on the reactor sidewall [58], parallel to the quartz glass and evenly distributed. This flow method creates an aerodynamic curtain wall that protects the quartz window from solid deposits caused by condensation and efficiently transports gaseous products to the reactor outlet. The flow of gases within the reaction chamber is therefore also an aspect to be considered in the actual design, mainly including the arrangement of the gas inlet and outlet and the influence of the shape of the chamber on the gas flow. Additionally, the total power absorbed by the metal oxide is influenced by the increasing gas flow rate and distance between the window and reactant [179]. Increasing the ratio of the characteristic length of the cavity to the window aperture can reduce the loss of outward radiation and approach the absorption rate of the black body.

Tescari et al. [180] developed a methodical approach to optimizing reactor geometry design. The method includes consideration of various technical and operational parameters that aid in determining the reactor type's optimal shape and maximum efficiency. The authors also scrutinized heat transfer and flow within the reactor and several performance standards, including safety, airtightness, and economy. The stability of the reactor can be quantified by the solar-to-fuel efficiency of the thermochemical cycle on a timescale, conversion rate of the reaction gas (H2O/CO2), and gas yield under identical conditions. To ensure that the reactor's performance does not significantly decrease with an increased number of cycles, the oxygen carrier of the thermochemical cycle must be cycled multiple times utilizing either a thermogravimetric analyzer or an infrared imaging furnace. Otherwise, if the oxygen carrier material requires replacement, it can negatively impact both the stability of the material and the airtightness of the reactor.

Currently, the cost of hydrogen production from thermochemical cycles is still below the target of $2/kg [181], meaning that it is not currently economically viable as an alternative to other sources of hydrogen. The cost of hydrogen production with Zn/ZnO as the thermochemical cycle oxygen carrier, with relative thermodynamic advantages, is approximately $5.02/kg to $14.75/kg [182]. Restrepo et al. [183] compared high-temperature electrolysis (HTE) with a thermochemical cycle and obtained maximum annual average solar-to‑hydrogen efficiencies of 31.8% and 10.2% for the HTE system and the metal oxide thermochemical cycle, respectively, with hydrogen production costs of $4.55/kg for HTE and $4.32/kg for the metal oxide cycle, which means that the combination of HTE and thermochemical cycles is a viable way to effectively reduce production costs. Reducing the cost of fuel production via thermochemical cycles requires considering multiple factors, including enhancing separation efficiency, optimizing component design, and refining system operating conditions. The cost of thermochemical cycle hydrogen production comprises several components, including the cost of the concentration system (e.g. tower concentration system, which includes heliostats, collector towers, and land cost), thermochemical reactor cost (material and processing cost), reaction material cost (water, carbon dioxide, circulating oxygen carrier, purge gas, calibration gas), gas separation cost (e.g. CO2/CO, H2O/H2, Zn/O2), heat exchanger cost, and vacuum pump cost (including equipment and energy consumption cost during use) [184].

One of the key ways to reduce process costs is to improve the separation process of the system. For instance, when using Zn/ZnO as a thermochemical cyclic oxygen carrier, it is crucial to separate Zn and O2 and improve the conversion rate of the oxygen support. It is also important to enhance the heat recovery efficiency, increase the installed capacity, optimize the component design, and optimize the operating conditions of the system (e.g. Zn/ZnO reaction temperature) [184]. These strategies can help to reduce the overall cost of hydrogen production through thermochemical cycles, making it more competitive with other methods of hydrogen production, such as high-temperature electrolysis and methane reforming.

With the increase in installed capacity, the price of thermochemical cycle hydrogen production has decreased to a certain extent, and Nicodemus et al. [185] used a learning curve to describe this trend. The cost c(t) spent on the time scale of hydrogen production methods is calculated as follows:

An overview of the design and performance optimization of solar thermochemical cycle reactors is detailed in the preceding sections. However, to ensure the achievement of an effective solar thermochemical cycle, it is essential to take into account not only the design of the reactor, but also focus on one of the vital components that facilitate its functionality, which is the solar concentration system. A solar concentrating system is the first step in the realization of a two-step thermochemical cycle, which can be achieved by means of solar tracking mirrors known as collectors or heliostats [186]. The following section discusses the types of concentrating systems that correspond to the thermochemical cycle to meet the needs of a particular reactor and analyzes the interactions between the solar concentrating system and the thermochemical cycle reactor to provide guidance for optimal performance and energy efficiency.

A conventional solar concentrating system generally consists of the concentrator, receiver, heat transfer system, energy storage system, and heat engine [187]. There are four primary collectors: a parabolic trough, tower central receiver, dish concentrator and linear Fresnel reflector [188] (Fig. 17 ), with the dish system and tower central receiver being the common choice for the two-step solar thermochemical cycle.

Thermochemical hydrogen production consumes water and heat, with heat being the key to the cycle. For a two-step thermochemical cycle, the metal oxide needs a high temperature to reach reactivity, but it is necessary to ensure that high temperature sintering of metal oxides is avoided [189]. However, the direct use of solar concentrating systems such as parabolic troughs and linear Fresnel reflectors to provide heat suffers from an inadequate concentration ratio, so the compound parabolic concentrator (CPC) can be used to secondary concentrate the concentrated solar energy. A detailed review of the development of CPC in the 21st century is presented by Tian et al. [190]. CPC has a higher solar energy collection efficiency than conventional concentrators, and the research of CPC will be an important solution for the future development of solar thermal chemistry, photovoltaic systems and light utilization. Among the four solar concentrators, the current dish concentrating method allows relatively easy access to high concentration ratios, which generally use tracking parabolic mirrors to concentrate the incident solar radiation at the focal point [191]. In certain circumstances, the tower concentrator could also be used for solar concentration which focuses solar radiation on a solar receiver mounted on top of the tower through a massive parabolic heliostat field [192].

The transient property of solar energy is a difficulty in the experimental testing of solar thermochemical cycles, the randomness of the outdoor environment is too great for controlling variables for in-depth studies and the time does not allow for long experiments to test material stability and verify repeatability. The High-Flux Solar Simulator (HFSS) is a high-flux solar simulator that delivers high-flux density radiation that closely approximates the natural spectrum. In comparison to solar field test beds, solar simulator systems are stable and controllable and are an excellent alternative for solar experiments [193].

Gallo et al. [195] and Tawfik et al. [196] provided overviews of research developments in high-throughput solar simulators for concentrated solar power. Xenon arc, metal halide, and argon lamps are the common types of solar simulators [197]. Xenon arc lamps in the visible and ultraviolet wavelengths can be used to maintain the stability of continuous operation (Fig. 18 ). However, it requires high-pressure gas filling, safety is difficult to guarantee, the power supply has high demands, and the output is highly unstable [194]. In the solar wavelength band, metal halide lamps have a balanced spectral quality. In comparison to xenon arc lamps, metal halide lamps have a longer life span, are less expensive, and can be safe [197]. The spectral distribution of argonarc lamps is similar to that of xenonarc lamps, with high energy emission in the infrared and high radiant fluxes in the UV.

Current solar simulators have several limitations. The lack of spectral accuracy means that the spectral distribution of the simulator varies from that of actual solar radiation,which can cause errors in measuring the performance of solar devices. Additionally, the intensity of the simulator is non-uniform across the illuminated area, which can also result in measurement errors. Third, the simulators do not account for variations in atmospheric and environmental conditions, including air mass and cloud cover. Furthermore, the variations in production models and manufacturers of solar simulators used by different research institutes can lead to inconsistencies in terms of error and accuracy, resulting in different experimental outcomes.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Coupling of solar concentrating systems and reactors
ce:section.ce:para: In the collaboration between the reactor and the heliostat field, our research primarily aims to optimize the distribution of solar radiation and precisely match it with the reactor [200,201]. The accurate matching between the focus of the concentrated field and the illuminated part of the reactor (direct heating type is a transparent window) is also a key factor in improving energy efficiency [202]. To ensure that the illuminance of the irradiation receiving surface of the reactor is evenly distributed, the Monte Carlo ray tracing algorithm [203] is usually used to calculate the defects of the mirror surface and accurately adjust the sensitivity of the heliostat steering [204]. It is also necessary to consider the influence of outdoor sunlight fluctuations on concentrated heat collection [205], which can ensure that the local high temperature points of the oxygen carrier and the internal temperature of reactor are within the tolerance range to ensure that the overall reception rate of the oxygen carrier is high [206,207]. Vidal et al. [198] designed a solar concentrator integrated system in this direction, where the ray tracing algorithm and the heliostat distribution were designed taking into account the variation of solar radiation under different times and seasons, as shown in Fig. 19(a)(b).

The reduction and oxidation reaction times of thermochemical cycle reactors are affected by the reaction rate constant of the material kinetic surface, resulting in inconsistent reaction times between the two steps [208]. The reduction reaction is a heat-absorbing reaction that must be carried out in the presence of light, whereas the oxidation reaction can be carried out without additional solar input after preheating. In the process of full reduction and moving the reactor, to reduce the loss of concentrated solar energy, other reactors that have been oxidized can be moved to the concentrating point. One method of efficiency enhancement is to alternate the redox steps between different reactors to match each other. The research by Dähler et al. [199] devised an optical arrangement (Fig. 19(c)) using two or more reactors to achieve continuous uninterrupted use of sunlight by alternating the solar input between them to perform two redox reactions simultaneously. Additionally, the additional concentrated solar energy can be used to melt metals or stored as thermal energy, fully utilizing the reactor's idle energy [209].

In this work, we review the progress made in the two-step solar fuel production process: from the material classification properties and synthesis process, the reactor and its principles of inter-selection with the materials and the basic calculation of the reactor concept efficiency, to the reactor development challenges, the simulation methodology and the design elements, and finally the coupling with the concentrating system.

Research on materials has always been a central focus of the field. Thermodynamic analysis necessitates the use of oxygen carrier materials with lower enthalpy of reduction and higher entropy change. Consequently, non-stoichiometric ratio materials like cerium oxide and perovskite have garnered significant attention as a current research topic. However, the challenge of driving the reaction and the limited degree of material conversion significantly restrict oxidation kinetics. Exploring doping strategies for materials can balance their reduction and oxidation reactions, but new approaches are necessary to achieve considerable enhancements in their overall properties.

The efficiency of the two-step solar thermochemical cycle is substantially below its theoretical value in practice, largely because the reactor and its associated components cause significant energy losses and consumption. To decrease thermal conductivity loss without compromising the thermochemical cycle efficiency, viable strategies include thickening the insulating layer, optimizing material longevity, and decreasing the specific surface area per unit volume of the reactor. Regarding oxygen removal, vacuum pumps and inert gas purging continue to encounter the issue of high energy consumption, which hinders the further improvement of system efficiency. In the future, attention will shift towards more energy-efficient methods of oxygen removal, including electrochemical and thermochemical oxygen pumping. However, despite these limitations, the technology is poised to achieve fuel conversion efficiencies comparable to, or even higher than, those seen in solar photovoltaic-driven electrolysis. This will be achieved through the introduction of heat recovery, optimization of the reactor structure and system arrangement, and the realization of reactor scale-up. To minimize or eliminate energy losses, further work is necessary at both the reactor and system level for commercial application of the technology.

Yongpeng Guo: Writing – original draft, Methodology. Jing Chen: Resources. Hualong Song: Investigation. Ke Zheng: Visualization. Jian Wang: Supervision. Hongsheng Wang: Writing – review & editing. Hui Kong: Supervision, Conceptualization.
